channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Test of Boeing Jet, Pilots Had 40 Seconds to Fix Error
item.media:description: A 737 Max 8 at Boeing’s plant in Renton, Wash. In simulations of a suspected problem in the crash of a Max 8 in Indonesia last fall, pilots had just moments to disengage a faulty system.
item.description: They had just moments to override an automated system and avert disaster in simulations of problems with the Lion Air plane that crashed last fall.
item.dc:creator: JACK NICAS, JAMES GLANZ and DAVID GELLES
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: Uber to Acquire Careem, Its Top Mideast Rival
item.media:description: A driver for Careem in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. A $3.1 billion deal for Careem could cut Uber’s losses in the Middle East.
item.description: The $3.1 billion deal, a break from Uber’s approach in some other regions, will give the ride-hailing company a strong foothold in the area ahead of its expected public offering.
item.dc:creator: KATE CONGER

item.title: Apple Unveils Video Service With Celebrity Parade but Few Details
item.media:description: Apple’s chief executive, Tim Cook, Oprah Winfrey, and Steven Spielberg at the company’s headquarters after the announcement of Apple’s new streaming-video service.
item.description: The iPhone maker is partnering with Hollywood heavyweights and publishers to provide broad new services to its users.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI and JOHN KOBLIN

item.title: Samsung Predicts Disappointing Results as Chip Prices Fall
item.media:description: Samsung’s announcement on Tuesday is the latest indication of waning global demand for sophisticated tech products.
item.description: Weaker demand for smartphones in China and elsewhere has put increasing pressure on the gadget industry.
item.dc:creator: BEN DOOLEY

item.title: State by State, Gig Companies Maneuver to Shape Labor Rules
item.media:description: Uber and Lyft argue that their drivers are contractors because the drivers decide when, where and how long they work. Lyft says forcing it to classify them as employees “may require us to significantly alter our existing business model.”
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.description: Lobbyists for clients like Uber and Handy are pressing legislatures, and sometimes working around them, to keep workers from being deemed employees.
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER

item.title: Hey, Look at Me! I’m a Venture Capitalist
item.description: As high-profile start-ups like Lyft, Pinterest and Uber prepare to go public, Silicon Valley venture capitalists are using the moment to shine the spotlight on themselves.
item.dc:creator: ERIN GRIFFITH

item.title: After Mueller Report, News Media Leaders Defend Their Work
item.media:description: The special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III, with his wife, Ann Mueller, on Sunday. “We are not investigators,” CNN’s president, Jeff Zucker, said. “We are journalists, and our role is to report the facts as we know them, which is exactly what we did.”
item.description: “Our job is to bring facts to light,” said Martin Baron, editor of The Washington Post. “Others make determinations about prosecutable criminal offenses.”
item.dc:creator: AMY CHOZICK
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Russian Roulette: The Inside Story of Putin's War on America and the Election of Donald Trump (Book)

item.title: At the 737 Max Factory, Pilots Simulate New Boeing Software
item.media:description: A Boeing 737 Max 8 plane at the Boeing plant in Renton, Wash.
item.description: Pilots from five airlines gathered in Renton, Wash., on Saturday to review proposed changes to the software of the 737 Max, two of which have crashed.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: China Pledges Openness in Hopes of Reaching a Trade Deal
item.media:description: A container ship in the Chinese port of Qingdao. Chinese exports to the United States have been hurt in an ongoing trade war.
item.description: Top Chinese officials, looking at a skeptical audience both at home and abroad, pledge to open the country’s markets to foreign investment.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Noted: Why Is Silicon Valley So Obsessed With the Virtue of Suffering?
item.media:credit: Photo illustration by Tracy Ma/The New York Times; Getty Images (vest)
item.description: The Stoics and friends continue to be the dominant thought leaders from Google to Apple — and a new entrepreneur lobbying firm has even named itself Cicero.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: Duke University to Pay $112.5 Million to Settle Claims of Research Misconduct
item.media:description: Duke University’s medical school. A dozen papers by a former researcher in the pulmonary, allergy and critical care department have been retracted since reports of falsified data surfaced.
item.media:credit: Madeline Gray for The New York Times
item.description: The university submitted falsified data in connection with 30 grants obtained from the N.I.H. and E.P.A., according to a whistle-blower lawsuit.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN

item.title: Museums Cut Ties With Sacklers as Outrage Over Opioid Crisis Grows
item.media:description: Protesters at the Guggenheim Museum last month dropped white slips of paper symbolizing OxyContin prescriptions. Last week the museum said it would no longer accept money from members of the family behind the drug.
item.description: Accusations that the family behind OxyContin actively downplayed its perils have led arts and education institutions to rethink accepting Sackler funds.
item.dc:creator: ALEX MARSHALL

item.title: WeWork’s Losses Swell to Nearly $2 Billion as It Seeks Global Expansion
item.media:description: A WeWork common space in Manhattan. The company argues that its roughly $2 billion in losses last year are commensurate with the size of its ambitions.
item.media:credit: Cole Wilson for The New York Times
item.description: The co-working start-up said that it lost about $1.9 billion last year, even as its revenue doubled amid breakneck growth in space and customers.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Susan Chira, Veteran New York Times Editor, Will Lead The Marshall Project
item.media:description: Susan Chira, a longtime reporter and editor at The New York Times, will succeed Bill Keller as editor in chief at The Marshall Project.
item.description: Ms. Chira, who shared a 2018 Pulitzer Prize for coverage of workplace sexual harassment, will succeed Bill Keller as the leader of a nonprofit news organization focused on criminal justice issues.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU
item.category: Knight, John S and James L, Foundation

item.title: Turkey to Investigate JPMorgan Over Charges It ‘Caused Volatility’ in the Markets
item.media:description: The Turkish lira, which has been slipping in value over the last year, slumped more than 5 percent on Friday.
item.description: With days until local elections, Turkey’s banking regulator accused JPMorgan Chase and other banks of issuing “misleading and manipulative” investment advice.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: An Ex-Fox News Host Pitched ‘Financial Freedom.’ His Clients Want Their Money Back.
item.media:description: Clayton Morris, a former "Fox and Friends Weekend" host, at his home in New Jersey. He and his wife offered to help average investors get into real estate, but many of the couple's clients say they lost thousands of dollars.
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.description: Clayton Morris has been sued by nearly two dozen customers who say they were sold ramshackle homes as investment properties.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Ex- Hong Kong Official Gets Lighter Sentence in Bribery Case
item.media:description: A federal judge gave Patrick Ho substantial credit for tutoring and counseling many inmates at the Manhattan Correctional Center when she sentenced him on Monday.
item.media:credit: Franke Tsang/South China Morning Post, via Getty Images
item.description: Patrick Ho, who was convicted in a bribery case connected to a Chinese oil company, received a lenient sentence partly because of good works in custody.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Book Entry: Review: How to Address Social Immobility? ‘The Human Network’ Offers a Road Map
item.description: The United States ranks toward the bottom of social mobility. Professor Matthew O. Jackson’s new book shows why proposals to reduce inequality won’t solve the problem of mobility.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN A. KNEE
item.category: The Price of Admission: How America's Ruling Class Buys Its Way Into Elite Colleges -- and Who Gets Left Outside the Gates (Book)

item.title: Jardinière, a Pioneer of High-End Dining and Design in San Francisco, Will Close
item.media:description: “My passion is moving me in a different direction,” said Traci Des Jardins. The chef is shown here in a 2007 photo taken at Jardinière.
item.description: The chef Traci Des Jardins says she’s ‘tired of fine dining’ and wants to focus on Mexican food.
item.dc:creator: KIM SEVERSON

item.title: Women at Breast Implant Hearing Call for Disclosure of Safety Risks
item.media:description: Holly Davis was among the women who testified about health concerns involving breast implants at an advisory panel hearing for the Food and Drug Administration.
item.media:credit: Greg Kahn for The New York Times
item.description: While industry representatives insisted the implants are safe, others at an F.D.A. panel meeting urged for warnings about links to illnesses and cancer.
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY and RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: Germany’s Second-Richest Family Discovers a Dark Nazi Past
item.media:description: A JAB Holding Company office building in Mannheim, Germany.
item.description: The Reimann family, with stakes in well-known brands like Krispy Kreme and Pret A Manger, have discovered that their predecessors used forced laborers.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Bayer and Johnson & Johnson Settle Lawsuits Over Xarelto, a Blood Thinner, for $775 Million
item.media:credit: Janssen Pharmaceuticals, Inc., via Associated Press
item.description: The settlement resolves about 25,000 lawsuits, which claimed the companies failed to warn about deadly bleeding episodes caused by the drug.
item.dc:creator: KATIE THOMAS

item.title: California Company Recalls Avocados From Six States Over Listeria Fears
item.media:description: The hand-packing process line at the Henry Avocado Corporation in Escondido, Calif. The company is recalling avocados sent to six states over listeria concerns.
item.description: The recalled avocados were packed at a facility in California and distributed in that state, Arizona, Florida, New Hampshire, North Carolina and Wisconsin.
item.dc:creator: MATT STEVENS

item.title: DealBook Briefing: Mueller’s Done, but Trump Still Faces the Law
item.media:description: The letter from Attorney General William Barr to Congress outlining principal conclusions from Robert Mueller’s report.
item.description: Legal challenges still stand in the way of the White House, despite Robert Mueller’s good news for President Trump.
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: He Tried to Bilk Google and Facebook Out of $100 Million With Fake Invoices
item.media:description: Evaldas Rimasauskas, seen in 2017, pleaded guilty to wire fraud last week.
item.description: A Lithuanian man pleaded guilty last week to wire fraud and said he was part of a scheme to imitate vendors and fraudulently invoice corporations.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Adventurous. Alone. Attacked.
item.media:description: Hannah Gavios in Queens, N.Y.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: The number of female solo travelers has skyrocketed, but amid Instagram-worthy escapades are tales of violence and death, raising questions about how the world is greeting women who travel alone.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA and TARIRO MZEZEWA

item.title: For Many Boys With Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy, Bright Hope Lies Just Beyond Reach
item.media:description: The parents of Henri Bigelow, 8, of Millcreek, Utah, hoped that he would qualify for the only gene-therapy trial for Duchenne muscular dystrophy that will accept boys his age. He did not.
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.description: Scientists are testing nearly two dozen treatments that might stop the disease. But enrollment in the trials is very restricted, and few children qualify.
item.dc:creator: GINA KOLATA

item.title: Global Stocks Fall as Pessimism Continues
item.description: Worries that the United States economy could slip into recession plagued investors for the second straight trading day. In Japan, the market fell 3 percent.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Mueller Report News Interrupts Sunday Golf and Video Games
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left: CNN, Fox News, MSNBC, and ABC as the Mueller report news broke on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: CNN, Fox News, NBC, ABC
item.description: The news media began assessing its own coverage of the investigation hours before a breaking story punctuated a long period of speculative TV talk.
item.dc:creator: JIM WINDOLF
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Viking Cruise Ship Stranded Off Norway Reaches Shore After Harrowing Rescue
item.media:description: Passengers on the Viking Sky waited to be evacuated on Saturday.
item.description: The Viking Sky was carrying more than 1,300 people when it sent a mayday alert Saturday. After recovering the use of some engines, the ship finally limped into port.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Cambodia Faces Major Economic Blow as E.U. Weighs Ending Trade Deal
item.media:description: A garment factory in Prey Nob, Cambodia. Since gaining access to the European market in 2001, the textile industry in the country has grown rapidly and now employs about 700,000 people.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: The country’s worsening rights record and oppression of the opposition could lead to the revoking of its special access to European markets.
item.dc:creator: SETH MYDANS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: DealBook Special: Everything You Need to Know About the Lyft I.P.O.
item.media:description: Lyft hopes to be valued at $23 billion when it makes its public market debut in the coming week.
item.description: How much will the company be valued at? What can go wrong? Who stands to get rich? Let us answer all those questions and more.

item.title: Cruise Ship Near Norway With Nearly 1,400 Passengers Is Being Evacuated
item.media:description: Nearly 1,400 passengers and crew members on board the Viking Sky were being evacuated on Saturday after the ship lost engine power.
item.media:credit: Odd Roar Lange/NTB scanpix, via Associated Press
item.description: Dramatic videos and photos on Twitter showed the ship listing, furniture sliding from one side to the other and water rushing on board.
item.dc:creator: MIHIR ZAVERI and SANDRA E. GARCIA

item.title: Boeing Was ‘Go, Go, Go’ to Beat Airbus With the 737 Max
item.media:description: Work on a 737 Max 8 this week at Boeing’s plant in Renton, Wash. When Airbus competed for a big order from American Airlines in 2011, Boeing opted to update its 737 rather than design a new jet.
item.description: Caught short by its rival’s gains, Boeing raced to update its workhorse jet rather than design a new one. Workers describe a hectic project, but say they hadn’t felt safety was compromised.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES, NATALIE KITROEFF, JACK NICAS and REBECCA R. RUIZ
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: Medicare for All Would Abolish Private Insurance. ‘There’s No Precedent in American History.’
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was joined by Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut and Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York to announce a Medicare for All bill in September 2017.
item.description: Unlike Obamacare, emerging plans would sweep away the private health insurance system. What would that mean for the companies’ workers, the stock market and the cost of care?
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON and MARGOT SANGER-KATZ
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

item.title: Sexual Assault on Flights: Experts Recommend Ways to Stay Safe and Combat It
item.media:description: Sexual assaults on flights have gained heightened attention by law enforcement, airline workers and the industry in the wake of high-profile cases and the #MeToo movement, officials say.
item.description: The issue gained heightened attention in the wake of high-profile cases and the #MeToo movement, officials say.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Tyson Recalls 69,000 Pounds of Chicken Strips After Metal Fragments Are Found
item.media:description: Tyson Foods, whose headquarters is in Springdale, Ark., is recalling 69,000 pounds of chicken strips.
item.description: A spokesman for the company said it would “continue to investigate” what happened.
item.dc:creator: CONCEPCIÓN DE LEÓN

item.title: With Interest: The Week in Business: Boeing Plays It Safe, and Lyft Kicks Off Tech I.P.O.s
item.description: Here’s your weekly smorgasbord of all the tech and business news you missed, plus what you should know heading into Monday.
item.dc:creator: CHARLOTTE COWLES

item.title: Pinterest Is Rare ‘Unicorn’ Preparing an I.P.O. Without Hemorrhaging Cash
item.media:description: In its offering prospectus, Pinterest reported $756 million in revenue in 2018, which came from advertising, up 60 percent from a year earlier, while it lost $63 million, compared with a net loss of $138 million in 2017.
item.description: The start-up, which lets people create virtual “pin boards,” officially joined the herd of tech companies stampeding to the public markets this year by unveiling its offering prospectus.
item.dc:creator: ERIN GRIFFITH

item.title: Mueller Speculation on TV Gives Way to Hard News. Then It’s Back to Speculation.
item.media:description: A TV camera outside the Justice Department on Friday.
item.description: Anchors posed questions for hours on Friday while waiting for the special counsel’s report to drop. When it did, there were few answers.
item.dc:creator: JOHN KOBLIN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Why Netflix Won’t Be Part of Apple TV
item.media:description: Jen Folse, lead designer for Apple TV, at the Apple Worldwide Developer Conference last June. On Monday, Apple plans to unveil a news and entertainment bundle, which will not include Netflix.
item.description: The first skirmishes have already been fought in what could turn into a tech cold war. “The game is on,” said the Netflix chief executive, Reed Hastings.
item.dc:creator: EDMUND LEE

item.title: Robert Kraft Awaits Your Judgment: ‘I Am Truly Sorry’
item.media:description: Tom Brady and Robert Kraft at the Super Bowl in 2019.
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Kevin C. Cox/Getty Images
item.description: Tom Brady, Meek Mill, Drew Bledsoe and Kenny Chesney on the man caught up in a scandal.
item.dc:creator: KATHERINE ROSMAN and KEN BELSON

item.title: Stocks Fall as Bond Market Flashes a Recession Warning
item.description: When long-term interest rates fall below short-term rates, it’s called a yield curve inversion. It’s one of Wall Street’s favored predictors of a recession, and it happened on Friday.
item.dc:creator: MATT PHILLIPS

item.title: G.M. Plans New Electric Vehicle Made at Chevy Bolt Plant
item.media:description: Mary T. Barra, the chief executive of General Motors, announcing on Friday that the company would invest $300 million in its plant in Orion Township, Mich.
item.description: The carmaker said it would invest $300 million in its Orion Township, Mich., plant in connection with producing the new model there.
item.dc:creator: ZACH WICHTER

item.title: Wealth Matters: The Teddy Bear Test, and Other Ways to Pass a State Tax Audit
item.media:description: Cities like Miami Beach, Fla., are attractive destinations for residents of the Northeast looking to cut their tax bills, and authorities in their former states are monitoring such moves.
item.description: Wealthy people with multiple homes may try to establish residency in lower-tax states to reduce their bill. Advisers say it’s a complicated task.
item.dc:creator: PAUL SULLIVAN

item.title: Bits: The Week in Tech: Our Future Robots Will Need Super-Smart Safety Checks
item.media:description: If software was at fault in the deadly crashes of two Boeing 737s like these, it raises questions about how technology that’s critical to safety is regulated.
item.description: Software looks to be at the heart of the recent Ethiopian Airlines crash. Safety approval of such systems will only get harder as technology advances.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE CONDLIFFE
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: DealBook Briefing: Rajat Gupta Won’t Say Sorry
item.media:description: Rajat Gupta.
item.description: The former head of McKinsey spent time in prison for tipping an insider-trading ring. Now, Mr. Gupta is speaking out — but not apologizing.
